children.name: fact
children.definition: a piece of information that can be proved to be true: sự thật (thông tin thật)
examples: ▪ I’m not interested in your opinions - I just want to know the facts.

children.name: fact about
examples: ▪ It’s important that young people learn the facts about drugs.
▪ The book is full of interesting facts about plant life.

children.name: fact that
examples: ▪ He’s never tried to hide the fact that he spent time in jail.

children.name: information
children.definition: facts or details that tell you something about a situation, person, event etc :
examples: I need more information.
For furtherinformation (= if you want to know more), please contact your local library.

children.name: useful/valuable
examples: The information he gave me was very useful.

children.name: correct/accurate
examples: Are you sure this information is correct?

children.name: wrong/false
examples: He was jailed for providing false information to the police.

children.name: relevant
children.definition: about the subject you are interested in
examples: Some of the information in the article is not particularly relevant.

children.name: confidential/secret
examples: That information was confidential and should not have been passed on.

children.name: more/further/additional information
examples: For more information, visit our website.

children.name: new information
examples: The police have received new information about the case.

children.name: the latest information
children.definition: information that has been discovered very recently
examples: We have access to all the latest information.

children.name: the necessary information
examples: This leaflet should provide you with all the necessary information.

children.name: detailed information
examples: More detailed information is available free on request.

children.name: financial/economic information
examples: The financial information contained in the report is based on the company's audited accounts.

children.name: background information
children.definition: information explaining what happened before the present situation
examples: He gave us some background information about the trial.

children.name: have information
examples: Do you have any information about coach trips to Oxford?

children.name: contain information
examples: The documents contained top secret information.

children.name: get/receive information
examples: It is vital that people receive the information they need.

children.name: collect/gather information
examples: The job consisted of gathering information about consumer needs.

children.name: need information
examples: When I needed information for my report, Jack was always extremely helpful.

children.name: look for information
children.definition: alsoseek informationformal
examples: Journalists going to the building to seek information were denied entry.

children.name: exchange information
children.definition: give information to each other
examples: The meetings provided an opportunity to exchange information.

children.name: disseminate informationformal
children.definition: give it to a lot of people
examples: The internet plays a key role in disseminating information.

children.name: a piece/bit of information
children.definition: alsoan item of informationformal
examples: He provided me with several useful pieces of information.

children.name: a source of information
children.definition: someone or something that can provide information
examples: Newspapers are valuable sources of information.

children.name: information that
examples: We have received information that Grant may have left the country.

children.name: information about/on
examples: The book contains information about a wide variety of subjects.

children.name: my/our etc information is(= used to say what you know about a situation )
examples: My information is that Gary wants to stay with the club.
RegisterIn everyday English, in informal contexts, people often use the expressiontell someone somethingrather than using the nouninformation:
I wonder if you couldgivemesome informationabout your childhood.➔I wonder if you couldtellmesomethingabout your childhood.

children.name: give/provide informationa booklet giving information about local education services
data
children.definition: 1 information or facts :
examples: The research involves collecting data from two random samples.
data on
data on pesticide use
experimental/historical/statistical etc data
detailed research data
Grammar :Afterdata, you can use a singular verb or, in formal or technical English, a plural verb :
The data is collected by trained interviewers.
These data are summarized in Table 5.
►Do not say 'datas’ or 'a data'.
2[U] information in a form that can be stored and used, especially on a computer :
It’s possible to store a lot more data on a DVD.
data storage/transfer/retrieval

children.name: accurate
examples: It’s important to ensure that the data we collect is accurate.

children.name: reliable
examples: Some of the data isn’t very reliable.

children.name: factual data
examples: It’s difficult to collect factual data on these insects.

children.name: historical/financial/scientific etc data
examples: My research involves analyzing the historical data.

children.name: statistical data
children.definition: based on statistics
examples: It is difficult to compare statistical data from different countries.

children.name: empirical data
children.definition: based on tests or experience, not on ideas
examples: The theory is supported by empirical data.

children.name: experimental data
children.definition: resulting from experiments
examples: the analysis of experimental data

children.name: survey/census data
children.definition: produced in a survey or census
examples: Survey data show that people’s participation in sports rises with their level of income.

children.name: raw data
children.definition: data that has been collected, but not organized or studied
examples: This system does no more than produce the raw data.

children.name: computer data
children.definition: kept on a computer
examples: Digital cameras transfer pictures and sound into computer data.

children.name: electronic data
children.definition: kept in an electronic form
examples: new ways of storing electronic data

children.name: collect data
examples: The survey data has been collected over the last three decades.

children.name: store data
examples: The data is stored on a computer in our central office.

children.name: process data
children.definition: store and organize it using computers
examples: Newer computers can process data much more quickly.

children.name: analyze data
examples: The researchers then began analyzing the data.

children.name: data shows something
examples: The data shows that suicide rates among young men have increased over the last twenty years.

children.name: data indicates/suggests something
examples: Our data indicates that weather patterns are likely to get more extreme.

children.name: a data base/data bank
children.definition: a large amount of data stored in a computer system
examples: We can compare insurance prices from different companies on the database.

children.name: data collection
examples: Choosing the right method of data collection will be crucial to the experiment’s success.

children.name: data processing
children.definition: using computers to store and organize information
examples: They’ve got a very efficient system for data processing.

children.name: data analysis
examples: Computers are increasingly used for data analysis.

children.name: a set of data
children.definition: one group of data
examples: The three sets of data produced strikingly different results.

children.name: a piece/item of data
examples: Every single piece of data is important.

children.name: a body of data
children.definition: a large amount of data
examples: There is an enormous body of data in support of the theory.

children.name: info
children.definition: /ˈɪnfəʊ/  especially spoken information:
examples: thông tin
▪ Sandra will give you all the info you need.
info on/about
thông tin trên/về
▪ For more info on the show, call this number.
▪ The dinosaur exhibit is pretty neat with lots of info about each period.

children.name: material
children.definition: information that is used when you write a story, article, speech etc: tài liệu,tư liệu
examples: His act contains a lot of new material.
There wasn’t enough material to write a whole book.
I’ve been unable to find any reference material on the subject of interracial adoptions.
The stories he collected became material for the biography he is now writing.

children.name: material for
examples: Anita is collecting material for a novel.

children.name: theraw material(= information that has not been carefully examined)for an article
examples: I'm in the process ofcollectingmaterial for an article that I'm writing.

children.name: notes
children.definition: information that you write down during a lesson, from a book etc :
examples: The wind blew my notes all over the room.
Can I borrow yourlecture notes?

children.name: take/make notes(= write notes )
examples: The journalist took notes throughout the interview.
I read the first chapter and took notes.

children.name: basics
children.definition: the most important and necessary facts about something, from which other possibilities and ideas may develop : thông tin căn bản
examples: The college can't even afford basics such as books and paper.
Here are some of the basics you will need to know.
basics of
the basics of French grammar
I really must learn the the basics of first aid.

children.name: point
children.definition: a single fact, idea, or opinion that is part of an argument or discussion : chi tiết, điểm
examples: That’s a very interesting point.
She made some extremely good points.
There are three important points we must bear in mind.
This brings me to my next point.

children.name: a good point
examples: I think that’s a very good point.

children.name: an interesting point
examples: He has made an interesting point.

children.name: an important point
examples: That’s an important point to bear in mind.

children.name: a serious point
examples: He’s making a joke but there is a serious point there as well.

children.name: a valid point
examples: She raised a number of valid points.

children.name: a general point
examples: I’d like to make one further general point.

children.name: a similar point
examples: Kevin Phillips made a similar point in his 1993 book, ‘Boiling Point’.

children.name: the main point
examples: Finally, I will summarise the main points of this chapter.

children.name: one final/last point
examples: There is one final point I would like to make.

children.name: make a point
examples: He makes the point that predicting behaviour is not easy.

children.name: put/get your point across
children.definition: make people understand it
examples: I think we got our point across.

children.name: raise a point
children.definition: mention it
examples: I was going to raise that point.

children.name: illustrate/demonstrate a point
examples: A simple example will illustrate the point.

children.name: prove your/a point
children.definition: prove that what you say is right
examples: He was determined to prove his point.

children.name: understand a point
examples: I’m sorry, I don’t understand your point.

children.name: see/take/get sb’s point
children.definition: understand or agree with it
examples: OK, I take your point. But it’s not that easy.

children.name: have a point
children.definition: have made a good point
examples: Maybe she has a point.

children.name: labour the pointBritish English,belabor the pointAmerican English
children.definition: keep saying something
examples: I don’t wish to labour the point, but why didn’t you just tell me?

children.name: clarify a point
children.definition: make it clearer
examples: Could you clarify a couple of points for me?

children.name: point taken
children.definition: used to say to someone that you accept what they say
examples: All right, point taken – I should have asked you first.

children.name: the finer points of sth
children.definition: the small details
examples: I’m afraid I don’t understand the finer points of the game.

children.name: point about
examples: I agree with John’s point about keeping the costs down.

children.name: detail
children.definition: a single fact or piece of information about sth: chi tiết

children.name: detail of
examples: She told me every detail of her trip.

children.name: down to the smallest/last detail(= completely )
examples: Todd had planned the journey down to the smallest detail.

children.name: thing
children.definition: spoken a detail in sth such as a plan, statement, or written agreement: chi tiết, điều, điểm
examples: There’s one thing I’m not clear about, and that’s how we are going to get to the airport.
In the new version of the story, a few things have been changed.

children.name: entry
children.definition: a separate piece of information that is recorded in a book, computer, etc : mục

children.name: a dictionary entry
examples: They've updated a lot of the entries in the most recent edition of the encyclopaedia.
As his illness progressed, hemadefewer entries in his diary.

children.name: informative
children.definition: providing a lot of new or useful information:
examples: The lecture was very informative and helpful.
Jim found the library staff friendly and informative.
The informative newsletter is published once every two months.

children.name: enlightening
children.definition: formal providing a lot of new or useful information: “làm sáng tỏ”
examples: The President described his conversation with the Russian leader as enlightening.
She has given us some truly enlightening insights into the subject of personality disorders.

children.name: file
children.definition: a collection of information, about a person, subject etc that is kept by an organization such as a school, a company, or the police: hồ sơ
examples: Only a few people are allowed to see these files.
police/case/medical etc file
a copy of the court file
file on
Could you bring me the file on the West murder, please?
keep a file on sb/sth
The FBI keeps files on all suspected terrorists.
The FBI keeps files on former White House employees.
keep sth on filestore it in a file
We keep copies of all applications on file.
We will keep your details on file(= store them for later use ).

children.name: record
children.definition: information that is collected gradually over a long period of time, so that it can be looked at when necessary: hồ sơ
examples: Our records are continually updated.

children.name: the records show something
examples: Official records show that 44 businesses have stopped trading in the last 12 months.

children.name: keep a record
examples: Teachers keep a record of students’ progress.

children.name: maintain a recordformal
examples: The directors are responsible for maintaining adequate accounting records.

children.name: place/put something on record
children.definition: officially say something or write it down
examples: I wish to put on record my objection to the scheme.

children.name: access records
children.definition: alsohave/gain access to records
examples: (= be able to look at them )Every citizen has the right to access their medical records.

children.name: a written record
examples: Where written records do survive, they are incomplete.

children.name: historical records
examples: Using historical records, we have produced an image of the temple.

children.name: official records
examples: This has been the wettest winter since official records began.

children.name: an accurate record
examples: Many hospitals did not keep accurate records.

children.name: a detailed record
examples: Edwardian travellers left detailed records of their journeys.

children.name: a proper record
examples: Failure to maintain proper records would be a criminal offence.

children.name: confidential records
examples: They were transferring confidential student records onto computer.

children.name: a permanent record
examples: You will have a permanent record of your work.

children.name: medical/hospital/health etc records
examples: The hospital could not find my mother’s medical records.|Patients’ hospital records are kept on a database.

children.name: financial records
examples: The company’s financial records must be up-to-date.

children.name: public records
children.definition: records of births, deaths etc, that the public are allowed to look at
examples: He found the information while examining public records.

children.name: police records
examples: Violent assaults rose 39 percent, according to police records.

children.name: the biggest/highest etc on record
examples: Last summer was one of the hottest on record.

children.name: a matter of public recordformal
children.definition: something that has been written down so that anyone can know it
examples: His salary is a matter of public record.

children.name: record of
examples: I try to keep a record of everything I spend.
According to official records, five people were killed last year near that road junction.
